title: examples
text: create basic flow using reactflow, need define nodes edges call reactflow function arguments. Note label node, provide label argument data list, whereas label direct argument edge. can change width output widget directly call [reactflow()]: default, can use connect new edges dragging one node another. disable , can set
code: nodes <- list(   list(id = "1", position = list(x = 0, y = 0), data = list(label = "Node 1")),   list(id = "2", position = list(x = 100, y = 100), data = list(label = "Node 2")),   list(id = "3", position = list(x = 0, y = 200), data = list(label = "Node 3")) )  edges <- list(   list(id = "e1-2", source = "1", target = "2", label = "Edge 1"),   list(id = "e2-3", source = "2", target = "3"),   list(id = "e1-3", source = "1", target = "3") ) reactflow(   nodes,   edges ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'. reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   width = "100%" ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'. reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   allow_edge_connection = FALSE,   width = "100%" ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'.

title: examples
text: reactflow package provides easy use UI elements customize usage display flow. Namely [background()], [controls()], [mini_map()],
code: reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   background = background(),   controls = controls(),   mini_map = mini_map(),   width = "100%" ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'.

title: examples
text: arguments passed background() passed underlying react-flow component. official background documentation can found : https://reactflow.dev/api-reference/components/background. example using extra arguments can found
code: nodes <- list(   list(id = "1", position = list(x = 0, y = 0), data = list(label = "Node 1")),   list(id = "2", position = list(x = 100, y = 100), data = list(label = "Node 2")),   list(id = "3", position = list(x = 0, y = 200), data = list(label = "Node 3")) )  edges <- list(   list(id = "e1-2", source = "1", target = "2", label = "Edge 1"),   list(id = "e2-3", source = "2", target = "3"),   list(id = "e1-3", source = "1", target = "3") )  reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   background = background() ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'. reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   background = background(     color = "beige",     variant = "lines",     gap = 50,     lineWidth = 2   ),   width = "100%" ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'.

title: examples
text: can also add multiple backgrounds flow passing multiple background() elements.
code: reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   background(     id = 1,     color = "beige",     variant = "lines",     gap = 40,     lineWidth = 3   ),   background(     id = 2,     size = 4,     offset = 3,     color = "lightgray",     variant = "dots"   ),   width = "100%" ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'.

title: examples
text: arguments passed controls() passed underlying react-flow component. official controls documentation can found : https://reactflow.dev/api-reference/components/controls. example using extra arguments can found
code: nodes <- list(   list(id = "1", position = list(x = 0, y = 0), data = list(label = "Node 1")),   list(id = "2", position = list(x = 100, y = 100), data = list(label = "Node 2")),   list(id = "3", position = list(x = 0, y = 200), data = list(label = "Node 3")) )  edges <- list(   list(id = "e1-2", source = "1", target = "2", label = "Edge 1"),   list(id = "e2-3", source = "2", target = "3"),   list(id = "e1-3", source = "1", target = "3") )  reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   controls = controls(),   width = "100%" ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'. reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   controls = controls(     position = "top-right",     orientation = "horizontal",     showZoom = TRUE,     showFitView = FALSE,     showIntereactive = TRUE   ),   width = "100%" ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'.

title: examples
text: arguments passed mini_map() passed underlying react-flow component. official miniMap documentation can found : https://reactflow.dev/api-reference/components/minimap.
code: nodes <- list(   list(id = "1", position = list(x = 0, y = 0), data = list(label = "Node 1")),   list(id = "2", position = list(x = 100, y = 100), data = list(label = "Node 2")),   list(id = "3", position = list(x = 0, y = 200), data = list(label = "Node 3")) )  edges <- list(   list(id = "e1-2", source = "1", target = "2", label = "Edge 1"),   list(id = "e2-3", source = "2", target = "3"),   list(id = "e1-3", source = "1", target = "3") )  reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   mini_map = mini_map(pannable = TRUE, zoomable = TRUE),   width = "100%" ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'.

title: examples
text: component can styled individually using CSS. Eg setting following CSS class, make nodes green. See also app.R TODO
code: .react-flow__node {   background-color: green !important; }

title: examples
text: Using classNames, can assign custom CSS nodes mini-map.
code: .startNode {   background-color: lightgreen; } .endNode {   background-color: coral; } nodes2 <- list(   list(id = "1", position = list(x = 0, y = 0), data = list(label = "Node 1"),        className = "startNode"),   list(id = "2", position = list(x = 100, y = 100), data = list(label = "Node 2")),   list(id = "3", position = list(x = 0, y = 200), data = list(label = "Node 3"),        className = "endNode") ) reactflow(   nodes = nodes2,   edges = edges,   mini_map = mini_map(),   color_minimap = TRUE,   width = "100%" ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'.

title: examples
text: official miniMap documentation can found : https://reactflow.dev/api-reference/components/minimap. example, nodeColor argument can used change color nodes mini map. Using classNames, can assign custom CSS nodes mini-map. TODO make minimap colorful
code: reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   mini_map = mini_map(     pannable = TRUE,     zoomable = TRUE,     nodeColor = "coral",     position = "top-right",     maskColor = "lightgray"   ),   width = "100%" ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'. .startNode {   background-color: lightgreen; } .endNode {   background-color: coral; } nodes2 <- list(   list(id = "1", position = list(x = 0, y = 0), data = list(label = "Node 1"),        type = "input"),   list(id = "2", position = list(x = 100, y = 100), data = list(label = "Node 2")),   list(id = "3", position = list(x = 0, y = 200), data = list(label = "Node 3"),        type = "output") ) reactflow(   nodes = nodes2,   edges = edges,   mini_map = mini_map(     nodeColor = JS("     function nodeColor(node) {       switch (node.type) {         case 'input':           return '#6ede87';         case 'output':           return '#6865A5';         default:           return '#ff0072';       }     }")   ),   color_minimap = TRUE,   width = "100%" ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'.

title: examples
text: little styling can applied [controls()] directly. However, can apply styling using CSS class react-flow__controls.

title: examples
code: library(reactflow)  nodes <- list(   list(id = "1", position = list(x = 0, y = 0), data = list(label = "1"), type = "input"),   list(id = "2", position = list(x = 50, y = 100), data = list(label = "2")),   list(id = "3", position = list(x = 100, y = 200), data = list(label = "3"), type = "output") ) edges <- list(   list(id = "e1-2", source = "1", target = "2", type = "straight"),   list(id = "e2-3", source = "2", target = "3", type = "smoothstep", label = "A",         animated = TRUE),   list(id = "e1-3", source = "1", target = "3", type = "bezier") )  reactflow(   nodes = nodes,   edges = edges,   background(variant = "dots", gap = 12, size = 2) ) #> Warning: `bindFillRole()` only works on htmltools::tag() objects (e.g., div(), #> p(), etc.), not objects of type 'shiny.tag.list'.

title: Creates a Background Component for a ReactFlow — background
code: nodes <- list(   list(id = "1", position = list(x = 0, y = 0), data = list(label = "1"),        type = "input"),   list(id = "2", position = list(x = 50, y = 100), data = list(label = "2")),   list(id = "3", position = list(x = 100, y = 200), data = list(label = "3"),        type = "output") ) edges <- list(  list(id = "e1-2", source = "1", target = "2"),  list(id = "e2-3", source = "2", target = "3"),  list(id = "e1-3", source = "1", target = "3") )  # basic background reactflow(nodes, edges, background())  {"x":{"tag":{"name":"ReactFlow","attribs":{"nodes":[{"id":"1","position":{"x":0,"y":0},"data":{"label":"1"},"type":"input"},{"id":"2","position":{"x":50,"y":100},"data":{"label":"2"}},{"id":"3","position":{"x":100,"y":200},"data":{"label":"3"},"type":"output"}],"edges":[{"id":"e1-2","source":"1","target":"2"},{"id":"e2-3","source":"2","target":"3"},{"id":"e1-3","source":"1","target":"3"}],"allow_edge_connection":true,"use_dagre":false,"dagre_direction":"LR","dagre_config":{"nodeWidth":200,"nodeHeight":40}},"children":[{"name":"Background","attribs":[],"children":[]}]},"class":"reactR_markup"},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]} # apply custom styling reactflow(nodes, edges, background(   color = "lightgreen",   size = 15,   variant = "cross", # see also "dots" and "lines"   gap = 50,   lineWidth = 2 ))  {"x":{"tag":{"name":"ReactFlow","attribs":{"nodes":[{"id":"1","position":{"x":0,"y":0},"data":{"label":"1"},"type":"input"},{"id":"2","position":{"x":50,"y":100},"data":{"label":"2"}},{"id":"3","position":{"x":100,"y":200},"data":{"label":"3"},"type":"output"}],"edges":[{"id":"e1-2","source":"1","target":"2"},{"id":"e2-3","source":"2","target":"3"},{"id":"e1-3","source":"1","target":"3"}],"allow_edge_connection":true,"use_dagre":false,"dagre_direction":"LR","dagre_config":{"nodeWidth":200,"nodeHeight":40}},"children":[{"name":"Background","attribs":{"color":"lightgreen","size":15,"variant":"cross","gap":50,"lineWidth":2},"children":[]}]},"class":"reactR_markup"},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]} # add two backgrounds reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   background(     id = "1",     color = "black",     variant = "lines",     gap = 10   ),   background(     id = "2",     color = "darkgray",     variant = "lines"   ) )  {"x":{"tag":{"name":"ReactFlow","attribs":{"nodes":[{"id":"1","position":{"x":0,"y":0},"data":{"label":"1"},"type":"input"},{"id":"2","position":{"x":50,"y":100},"data":{"label":"2"}},{"id":"3","position":{"x":100,"y":200},"data":{"label":"3"},"type":"output"}],"edges":[{"id":"e1-2","source":"1","target":"2"},{"id":"e2-3","source":"2","target":"3"},{"id":"e1-3","source":"1","target":"3"}],"allow_edge_connection":true,"use_dagre":false,"dagre_direction":"LR","dagre_config":{"nodeWidth":200,"nodeHeight":40}},"children":[{"name":"Background","attribs":{"id":"1","color":"black","variant":"lines","gap":10},"children":[]},{"name":"Background","attribs":{"id":"2","color":"darkgray","variant":"lines"},"children":[]}]},"class":"reactR_markup"},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}

title: Creates a Control Component for a ReactFlow — controls
code: nodes <- list(   list(id = "1", position = list(x = 0, y = 0), data = list(label = "1"),        type = "input"),   list(id = "2", position = list(x = 50, y = 100), data = list(label = "2")),   list(id = "3", position = list(x = 100, y = 200), data = list(label = "3"),        type = "output") ) edges <- list(  list(id = "e1-2", source = "1", target = "2"),  list(id = "e2-3", source = "2", target = "3"),  list(id = "e1-3", source = "1", target = "3") )  # basic control reactflow(nodes, edges, controls())  {"x":{"tag":{"name":"ReactFlow","attribs":{"nodes":[{"id":"1","position":{"x":0,"y":0},"data":{"label":"1"},"type":"input"},{"id":"2","position":{"x":50,"y":100},"data":{"label":"2"}},{"id":"3","position":{"x":100,"y":200},"data":{"label":"3"},"type":"output"}],"edges":[{"id":"e1-2","source":"1","target":"2"},{"id":"e2-3","source":"2","target":"3"},{"id":"e1-3","source":"1","target":"3"}],"allow_edge_connection":true,"use_dagre":false,"dagre_direction":"LR","dagre_config":{"nodeWidth":200,"nodeHeight":40}},"children":[{"name":"Controls","attribs":[],"children":[]}]},"class":"reactR_markup"},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]} # apply custom styling reactflow(nodes, edges, controls(   position = "top-right",   orientation = "horizontal",   # show values can be turned off, on by default   showZoom = TRUE,   showFitView = FALSE,   showIntereactive = TRUE ))  {"x":{"tag":{"name":"ReactFlow","attribs":{"nodes":[{"id":"1","position":{"x":0,"y":0},"data":{"label":"1"},"type":"input"},{"id":"2","position":{"x":50,"y":100},"data":{"label":"2"}},{"id":"3","position":{"x":100,"y":200},"data":{"label":"3"},"type":"output"}],"edges":[{"id":"e1-2","source":"1","target":"2"},{"id":"e2-3","source":"2","target":"3"},{"id":"e1-3","source":"1","target":"3"}],"allow_edge_connection":true,"use_dagre":false,"dagre_direction":"LR","dagre_config":{"nodeWidth":200,"nodeHeight":40}},"children":[{"name":"Controls","attribs":{"position":"top-right","orientation":"horizontal","showZoom":true,"showFitView":false,"showIntereactive":true},"children":[]}]},"class":"reactR_markup"},"evals":[],"jsHooks":[]}

Shiny bindings for reactflow — reactflow-shiny
text: Output render functions using reactflow within Shiny applications interactive Rmd documents.

title: Shiny bindings for reactflow — reactflow-shiny
code: reactflowOutput(outputId, width = "100%", height = "400px")  renderReactflow(expr, env = parent.frame(), quoted = FALSE)

title: Shiny bindings for reactflow — reactflow-shiny
text: outputId output variable read width, height Must valid CSS unit (like '100%', '400px', 'auto') number, coerced string 'px' appended. expr expression generates reactflow env environment evaluate expr. quoted expr quoted expression (quote())? useful want save expression variable.

title: A — reactflow
code: reactflow(   nodes,   edges,   controls = NULL,   mini_map = NULL,   background = NULL,   allow_edge_connection = TRUE,   use_dagre = FALSE,   dagre_direction = c("LR", "TB"),   dagre_config = list(nodeWidth = 200, nodeHeight = 40),   ...,   width = NULL,   height = NULL,   elementId = NULL )
